+ Must and have to can be used interchangably. However, must cannot be used in the past tenses, hence past form of have to - had to is usually substituted.

+ don’t have to is used to show that there is no obligation. You can do something if you want to but it’s not compulsory.

explanation:
Have to = must
Some notes about must and have to:
+ Must and have to can be used interchangably. However, must cannot be used in the past tenses, hence past form of have to - had to is usually substituted.
+ While must expresses the obligation from the speaker, have to is used to imply that obligation comes from others, that the speaker cannot change.
+ don’t have to is used to show that there is no obligation. You can do something if you want to but it’s not compulsory.

explanation:
Have to = must
Some notes about must and have to:
+ Must and have to can be used interchangably. However, must cannot be used in the past tenses, hence past form of have to - had to is usually substituted.
+ While must expresses the obligation from the speaker, have to is used to imply that obligation comes from others, that the speaker cannot change.
+ don’t have to is used to show that there is no obligation. You can do something if you want to but it’s not compulsory.

explanation:
The present tense of “to lie” is “lies.” “Lays” is the present tense of the transitive (taking a direct object) verb “to lay,” e.g. “We lay books on this table.” “Has laid” should be “has lain,” but present perfect makes no sense here: San Francisco’s location has not moved. 

Present progressive “is lying” is similarly misleading regarding a non-temporary location. “Lain” is present perfect/past perfect, not present-and moreover lacks its auxiliary verb (has/had).

explanation:
Have to = must
Some notes about must and have to:
+ Must and have to can be used interchangably. However, must cannot be used in the past tenses, hence past form of have to - had to is usually substituted.
+ While must expresses the obligation from the speaker, have to is used to imply that obligation comes from others, that the speaker cannot change.
+ don’t have to is used to show that there is no obligation. You can do something if you want to but it’s not compulsory.
options: has to///don’t have to///doesn’t have to
